--- title: Pectineus Muscle --- ![Hip and Thigh Muscles @OpenStaxAnatomyPhysiology2022](/The Archive/Images/OpenStax Anatomy and Physiology 2e/fig11.29 Hip and Thigh Muscles.jpeg){#fig-openstax-fig11.29} ![Muscles of the Iliac and Anterior femoral regions @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Myology/image430 Muscles of the iliac and anterior femoral regions.gif) ![Deep muscles of the medial thigh @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Myology/image433 Deep muscles of the medial femoral region.gif) ::: {.callout title="Reading list"} - Ch59 Adductor Longus, Adductor Brevis, Adductor Magnus, Pectineus, and Gracilis Muscles @donnellyTravellSimonsSimons2019 - Neuman @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - MMT @weinstockNeuroKineticTherapyInnovative2010 ::: ::: {#tbl-oian .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Pectineus Pecten pubis Pectineal line
Proximal linea aspera		 Femoral n.
Obturator n.
L2 - L3		 Hip: ER, Adduction, *slight* Flexion
Pelvis: Frontal plane stabilization, Sagittal plane stabilization
``` ::: ::: # Origin {#origin} Pecten Pubis @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Insertion {#insertion} Femur (pectineal line and proximal linea aspera) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Innervation {#innervation} - [Femoral N.]({{< var ref-femoral-nerve.path >}}), ref-obturator-nerve ([L2]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l2 >}}), [L3]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l3 >}})) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Action {#action} - **Hip joint**: ER (when >30-40° hip IR), ADD, slight flex - **Pelvis**: Stabilization in coronal and sagittal plane At ~30-40° of *internal rotation*, the pectineus runs exactly inferior to the center of the joint, and thus stops functioning as an external rotator @jonesProjectFoundations2025. When the hip is internally rotated past 40°, the pectineus generates an external rotation torque @jonesProjectFoundations2025.
